speaker: Frasier
text: Till tomorrow then, this is Dr. Frasier Crane wishing you... _Roz knocks on the booth.  Frasier looks around a sees a grumpy old man looking in through the screen._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes.  Be sure to tune in later for the final broadcast of KACL's loveable curmudgeon, Chester Ludgate.  You know, most of us here at the station were surprised to hear that he was retiring.  I for one thought he'd never leave. [_presses button_]

speaker: Roz
text: [_enters_] So, should we order a pizza?

speaker: Frasier
text: Sorry?

speaker: Roz
text: Those PSA's you promised you'd help me with are due tomorrow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh gosh, Roz, I really am sorry.  You know, it seems Mrs. Delafield's daughter is coming here to join us as an intern. I promised Kenny I'd show her around and take her to dinner.

speaker: Roz
text: So, while I'm working late, eating my vending-machine dinner, you'll be out having a gourmet meal with some cute rich girl.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you can make anything sound unfair. _Roz exits to her booth as Kenny and the cute rich girl, Poppy, enter the booth.  Poppy is like a character out of "Clueless": Long blond hair, dressed totally in a red "girly" outfit with red high heels and red hand bag.  She speaks with an annoying, ditzy accent._

speaker: Kenny
text: Hey, Doc.

speaker: Frasier
text: Kenny, and who have we here?

speaker: Kenny
text: Dr. Frasier Crane, I'd like you to meet Miss Poppy Delafield. Well, gotta run. [_swiftly exits_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Poppy, what a pleasure to meet the daughter of our beloved station owner.  So, what brings you to KACL?

speaker: Poppy
text: Well, I was in Paris last month - or was it Madrid? - No, Paris, and I said to myself, "that's enough gallivanting for you, young lady, it's time to get a job."  So I flew home and asked my mother, Minnie, if I could nose around and see if some job, you know, spoke to me at one of her radio stations, or TV stations or newspapers.  But not her brewery, thank you very much!  So, here I am.  Sleeves rolled up, ready to learn.  Is this where you do your show? Of course it is, there's your mike right in front of me. Earth to Poppy!

speaker: Poppy
text: There's Gil, I met him earlier.  Hi, Gil! _She waves, Gil runs away.  Frasier also waves and then wonders what he is doing and looks back at Poppy, who carries on._

speaker: Poppy
text: Nice man.  I think it's marvelous what you do.  To really help people.  Unlike the psychiatrists I've been to, both of whom had some sort of, I don't know, narcolepsy.  I sympathize, but if you can't stay awake, don't be a psychiatrist! _Behind her back, Frasier removes his cell phone, dials a number, and then hides it in his pocket._

speaker: Poppy
text: To do what you do, to face that microphone day after day and know that for the next three hours you're going to have to talk and talk and talk?  I could not do it!  I would freeze! Literally freeze!

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me. [_grabs the phone_] Hello?  Yes, Dad.  All right, calm down, calm down.  Was there much blood?

speaker: Poppy
text: Oh my gosh!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Dad, I'll be there as soon as I can, hang on a second. [_puts phone to chest, to Poppy_] I'm terrible sorry, there's been a small emergency at home.  I'm gonna have to pass on today, may I take a rain check?

speaker: Poppy
text: Oh, and we were having such a nice chat.

speaker: Frasier
text: This is Roz, my producer.  You know Roz, I'll gladly do those promos if you would be so kind as to take Poppy to dinner and answer her questions.

speaker: Roz
text: Sure, if you don't get bored listening to me drone on about radio.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I don't think there's much chance of that! _Poppy whizzes Roz out of the booth, chatting to her on the way.  FADE OUT  Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment. Frasier and Daphne are sitting at the dining table.  Martin enters and hurries Eddie into the apartment, checking the hallway for people._

speaker: Frasier
text: What the hell is happening?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, remember last week when Eddie killed his first rat? And how proud I was?  I told you that story, right?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Dad, you told us.  If you had a guitar you would have written a ballad.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, we were just down in the basement and I saw another rat. I said, "go get him, boy!"  So just as he picked him up, had him in his teeth, shaking the life out of him, and I hear this little bell, ting-a-ling.  And I thought, "that's funny - rats don't wear bells!"

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, little Robbie Greenberg's missing hamster!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I read that flyer.  He was offering a ten dollar reward.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, the most we can claim at this point is about six-fifty.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know Dad, this is actually your fault.  You know if you hadn't encouraged him after he killed his first rat he wouldn't have moved on to murdering hamsters!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, what are you talking about?  We don't know it was Eddie who killed him.  He might have had a heart attack, or some kind of seizure when he bounced off the boiler! _The doorbell sounds.  Frasier crosses the room and opens the door to Niles.  He is carrying a magazine and two tickets. A smile is beaming across his face._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: Prepare to whoop like a sweepstakes winner.  Cancel our dinner!  I've scored us two seats, front row for the event of the season.

speaker: Frasier
text: You mean...?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: But...?

speaker: Niles
text: I know! [_proudly holds up the tickets_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!

speaker: Martin
text: [_aside to Daphne_] I love it when they do it this way, I can pretend it's a Seahawks game. _He sits in his chair as Frasier eagerly takes the tickets and scans them._

speaker: Frasier
text: My God, it's for the Cecilia Bartoli concert!  My God, they've been sold out for months.  How on earth did you score these tickets?

speaker: Niles
text: I simply phoned the box office and said this is Niles Crane, the new arts critic for "The Monocle." _Frasier takes in a gasp of half delight for his brother and half jealousy as Niles slaps the magazine on the table._

speaker: Daphne
text: "The Monocle."  Isn't that that magazine they hand out to rich people in all the snootiest apartment buildings?

speaker: Niles
text: And the snootiest hotels.

speaker: Frasier
text: How could this happen, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: I was at a party thrown by the publisher, Olga Suerbread. The pretentious fop who had the job before me was there too, spouting sheer drivel about Leonard Bernstein.  Being polite I kept my tongue sheathed.  Until he referred to Bernstein's conducting as "overrated."

speaker: Frasier
text: [_indignant_] I assume you pounced?

speaker: Niles
text: [_dignified_] Like a ninja!  By the time I had finished with him, Olga could see I was a far better critic than that arrogant poseur.

speaker: Daphne
text: She fired him right there?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, he was leaving anyway for his junior year abroad.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's a post.  Congratulations are in order.  You know, who would have thought my little brother a professional music critic?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, oh, and not just music.  I can review anything I want. Theater, dance, art exhibits.

speaker: Frasier
text: You don't say?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, from now on, wherever we go, I'll be armed with my trusty pad and penlight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Wherever we go?  What fun.

speaker: Niles
text: [_takes some opera glasses from his pocket_] I'll have to take a damp cloth to these opera glasses, although I don't know what will we use them for, sitting in the front row?  Unless it's to scan the faces of the jealous people behind us.

speaker: Martin
text: So, are you sure you're okay with Niles getting this critic job?

speaker: Frasier
text: Why wouldn't I be, Dad?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, come on, I know what it's like with you two when one of you gets something the other one doesn't have.  It's like when you were kids.  Niles got a telescope, so you had to have a telescope.  You got that funny little guitar, Niles...

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, it was called a lute!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh yeah, whatever.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, believe me, I do not envy Niles his critic's job.  As kids we would aggravate the situation by flaunting our toys in each other's faces.  We're much more mature than that now, all right?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you know, it's about time we got going.  We don't want to be late for the curtain.

speaker: Niles
text: [_flaunting_] Don't be silly, I'm press now.  They'll hold it. _Niles walks out with great esteem, his chin pointed up.  Frasier grovels behind him, ignoring Martin's smug look.  FADE TO:_ **HOW A POPPY BECOMES HEROIN** _Scene Three - Caf e Nervosa. Front stage, Frasier and Roz are having a coffee and a chat together. Meanwhile upstage, Poppy is telling a weary crowd around her (including Gil and Kenny) about her life. _

speaker: Poppy
text: So, that's how it ends: B minus average, ten extra pounds and still no boyfriend.

speaker: Roz
text: I see Poppy's having a little party.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's not a party, that's a hostage situation.

speaker: Roz
text: Thank God today is her last day.  You know, this morning she cornered me by the coffee machine and told me her whole life story.  I just wanted to grab her by the throat and say, "What am I, your biographer?  Shut up!" _Frasier laughs.  Gil finally gets out of the "party" and arrives at Frasier's table._

speaker: Gil
text: Dear God!  I thought I'd never break free.  I feel like a mongoose at the mercy of a chatty cobra.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, all.  I see you all ready have the "Times."  I'm quoted there today.

speaker: Frasier
text: In the "Times?"

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, here, [_shows Roz the bit_] it's in an ad for "St. Joan": "'Incandescent,' Niles Crane, 'The Monocle.'"

speaker: Roz
text: [_stands_] Wow!  Excuse me while I go and tell all my friends I know you!

speaker: Niles
text: [_yawns_] Forgive me.  Olga and I were up till all hours at a party for the "Royal Shakespeare Company."  I'm rubbing pretty impressive shoulders these days.  And to think it's all because I have a small column.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_keeping his eyes on his newspaper_] That would certainly be the Freudian interpretation!

speaker: Niles
text: If I were to review that attitude I would say it was a chilling portrait of malice and envy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, I'm not the least bit envious that you get to spout off in that glorified cat-box liner.

speaker: Niles
text: You just can't stand it that my opinion means more than yours.  That the arts community looks to me for my insight, my approval, my thumbs-up.

speaker: Frasier
text: I think we both know what your thumb's up these days!

speaker: Niles
text: That's a good one, Frasier.  Perhaps you should use it in your column.  Oh, that's right - you don't HAVE one!

speaker: Frasier
text: That smug jackass!

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, you have a radio show.  If you wanted to say what you thought of a play, what's stopping you?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's not the same thing as being a real critic, Roz.  You don't get free tickets... you don't get quoted... forget hobnobbing.

speaker: Roz
text: My God, this competition between you and your brother is sick. Your obsessive one-upmanship.  You're both going to end up bitter old cranks like Chester Ludgate.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, you do raise a good point, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Chester's time slot is free, I could do my own arts show.

speaker: Frasier
text: Kenny?  Listen, Roz just had a wonderful idea.

speaker: Kenny
text: Yeah, doc?

speaker: Frasier
text: What do you say about yours truly hosting a bouncy little show about the arts in Seattle?

speaker: Kenny
text: Culture? Wow!  That's a great idea, let me chew on that and I'll get back to you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Great!  You see, Roz, he loved your idea

speaker: Roz
text: That was not my idea.

speaker: Frasier
text: It was too your idea.

speaker: Roz
text: It was not...

speaker: Kenny
text: Look, Doc, honestly, I feel kinda bad about what I just did. I let you think there was a chance that I might you let you do this culture show and... there's not.

speaker: Frasier
text: No chance at all?

speaker: Kenny
text: No.  I mean, come on Doc.  You, culture, opera.  Who's listening?  Not me! [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn!  I think my show's a good idea.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, Kenny's the station manager and he doesn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know what, frankly, I don't like his attitude.  He acts as if he owns the station but he doesn't.  Someone else does.

speaker: Roz
text: Poppy!

speaker: Frasier
text: The next best thing, her mother!

speaker: Roz
text: No, Poppy. _Roz points to Poppy who is coming over.  Roz quickly picks up her bag and exits._

speaker: Poppy
text: Hi, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Poppy.  Gosh, would you care to join?

speaker: Poppy
text: I can't.  Mummy's taking me shopping.  She spoils me something horrible, I guess it's an "only child" thing.  Anything I want, I just have to ask.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_getting an idea_] Anything you want?  Well, that's interesting.  You know, Poppy, we could join each other for lunch after your shopping spree.

speaker: Poppy
text: Oh, I'd love it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Would you really?  You know, it just seems a shame you leaving the station and us never really getting to know one another.

speaker: Poppy
text: Oh, it hasn't been easy.  I mean, with you having those dental appointments everyday.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_guilty_] Yes.  Let me walk you out. [_stands up_]

speaker: Poppy
text: You know, I should get the name of your dentist.  I can't find one I like.  They're always giving me Novocaine when I don't need it and then it's hours before I can talk again.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, well, I can give you his number, although I'm not sure he'd be any different. _Frasier and Poppy exit.  End of Act One.  Act Two.  Scene One - Frasier's Apartment. Daphne is sat, irritated, on Martin's chair.  Frasier and Poppy are sat on the sofa with wine and pat e on the table.  The last chords of a Beethoven piece is being played on the stero.  Frasier is air- conducting as Poppy is laid back listening. _

speaker: Frasier
text: Divine Beethoven.  Extraordinary, isn't it?

speaker: Poppy
text: Oh, yeah.  And do you know what makes it more amazing?

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Poppy
text: [_declares_] He was deaf!

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, more pate please. _Daphne picks up the pat e dish still staring at Poppy before she exits to the kitchen. _

speaker: Frasier
text: Poppy, I can't tell you how wonderful it is to meet someone who shares my passion for the arts.  It's a rare thing to find in Seattle, believe me.

speaker: Poppy
text: Is it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, sadly.  If only more people were better informed about our city's rich cultural treasures. [_hinting_] But what can we as mere radio folk do?

speaker: Poppy
text: Well... [_delayed reaction_] What about a radio show all about the arts in Seattle?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh my God, Poppy, that's a wonderful idea.  How do you do it, you just pull these things out of the air!  Good Heavens, of course we'll have to find ourselves a proper host, but who?

speaker: Poppy
text: Well someone very smart.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, indeed.

speaker: Poppy
text: And cultured.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_French_] _Bien Sur!_

speaker: Poppy
text: And with a lovely speaking voice.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_articulated_] Oh, I don't think we need to look too far. _Daphne enters with the pat e. _

speaker: Daphne
text: Here you go.  It's very rich, so don't spread it on too thick!

speaker: Poppy
text: Frasier, I'm so glad you're on board with this.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, my only concern is will Kenny go for it?  You see, he's a bit of a Philistine.  It might be better if the suggestion came not actually from us but from... [_no response_] someone else.

speaker: Poppy
text: Who?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, someone with more authority, power, influence... [_no response_] Someone older... [_no response_] A woman perhaps... [_no response_]

speaker: Daphne
text: [_fed up_] Your mother!  He means your mother!

speaker: Poppy
text: Oh, what a great idea.  I'll call her. [_stands_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Here, use mine.

speaker: Poppy
text: Thank you.

speaker: Poppy
text: Hello, mummy.  I'm with Frasier Crane and we think there should be an arts show on KACL.  But I really like this idea! So, you'll call Kenny and tell him you want this, okay?  Love you too, okay, bye. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Poppy
text: And the first show should be?

speaker: Frasier
text: Why don't we start tomorrow?  But we'll need something to review.

speaker: Poppy
text: That revival of "A Streetcar Names Desire" opens tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Brilliant, let's go together.  I'll see you at the theater. _Poppy gets up to the door and is greeted by Martin who enters with Eddie._

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, Poppy.

speaker: Poppy
text: [_to Eddie, loudly as if he is a baby_] Hewwo, wittle Eddie, did you have a good walk? [_Eddie runs off_]

speaker: Martin
text: Actually, we've just been to the vets.

speaker: Poppy
text: [_standing in door way_] I had the cutest little dog when I was young, named Mr. Poops, every time we took him to the vet's he...

speaker: Daphne
text: You took Eddie to the vet, is he sick?

speaker: Martin
text: No, it turns out the building security camera caught Eddie taking out Robbie Greenberg's hamster.  So this Greenberg kid's trying to make Eddie out to be some kind of pit bull, he's organizing some petition to get him banned from the building.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_repressing glee_] Oh Dad, that's terrible.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, it is.  I don't know, I just wanted everyone to see what a nice, calm, friendly dog Eddie was.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why did you take him to the vet?

speaker: Martin
text: Tranquilizers.  They don't even work anyway.  I gave Eddie one of those pills on the ride home, they didn't do a thing to him.  I don't know, I think maybe he needs something else.

speaker: Daphne
text: Uh, Mr. Crane? _Daphne points to Eddie laid, seemingly unconscious, on the upstage floor.  Martin looks._

speaker: Frasier
text: Looks like all he needs is a lava lamp and some sitar music. _The doorbell sounds.  Frasier crosses to the door and opens it to Niles._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm glad to see you're in a better mood.  I was hoping you'd lend me your Tennessee Williams biography.  I have to review that revival of "Streetcar" tonight and I wanted to throw in some background stuff.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm sorry Niles, you know, normally I would have lent it, but I'll be needing it myself for my own review.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.  Well, in that case I'll... [_realizes_] What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's right, you wouldn't have heard.  You see, starting tomorrow I'll be doing my own little arts show on KACL, twice weekly.

speaker: Niles
text: You envious reptile!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_picks up plate_] Pate?

speaker: Niles
text: I achieve one thing, one tiny distinction you don't have, and what do you do?  You run whining to Kenny for extra airtime.

speaker: Frasier
text: I did no such thing!

speaker: Daphne
text: No, he went to that Poppy woman instead.

speaker: Niles
text: Poppy?!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Daphne_] Is this a panel discussion?

speaker: Niles
text: You loathe Poppy!

speaker: Frasier
text: I do not, I think she's delightful, [_to Daphne_] isn't she?

speaker: Daphne
text: She's an idiot!

speaker: Niles
text: You conniving copy-cat!  You have to have whatever I have.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't have what you have.  My audience is twice as large as yours is!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, at least my audience can read!

speaker: Frasier
text: How dare you review my audience!

speaker: Niles
text: I'll review anything I want to! _Niles and Frasier, bickering, exit to the kitchen.  Martin is laid back in his chair listening to them as Daphne watches Eddie._

speaker: Daphne
text: [_referring to Eddie_] I've never seen him like this.  Eyes bulging, tongue lolling out...

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, he always gets that way when he fights with Niles! _FADE TO:  Scene Two - Radio Station. Roz is in her booth getting ready for the show as Frasier enters._

speaker: Frasier
text: Good morning, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Hi.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you ready for our debut?  I'm thinking of calling the show, "Frasier Crane's 'I'll Say'."  But with the "I'll" spelt like a theatre aisle.

speaker: Roz
text: [_sarcastic_] That should work real well on radio!  You better watch out for Kenny, I heard he's pretty mad at you for going over his head.

speaker: Frasier
text: He can't be mad at me, the whole thing was Poppy's idea. [_Poppy runs by outside_] Oh, here she is now, come to wish me luck.

speaker: Poppy
text: I was afraid I wouldn't get here in time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, here, here. [_sits her down in his chair_] We've got a few minutes to go before the show starts.  Take a seat, catch your breath.  Oh gosh, I'm really glad you made it.  You know, it wouldn't be a proper debut without you.

speaker: Poppy
text: Wow!  All these buttons, how do you do it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, it's not that complicated, really.  You know, I turn on the mike here, these are my call buttons.  Oh, and I push this button here if I want to cough. [_shows her_]

speaker: Poppy
text: How does it make you cough?

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Poppy, I hate to rush you, but we've just a couple of minutes before the show so...

speaker: Poppy
text: [_screams and stands up, only to sit back down again taking a script out of her handbag_] I better get a move on. [_reads her script_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Poppy, what are you doing?

speaker: Poppy
text: Getting ready for my show.

speaker: Roz
text: [_confused_] One minute!

speaker: Frasier
text: Your show?

speaker: Poppy
text: Well, okay, our show.  After all, it was your idea for me to do it. [_shouts_] Everybody, everybody come in here, please. _Everybody from the corridors comes to the doorway to listen to her. Even Kenny and Gil stand by._

speaker: Poppy
text: Before I begin my new show I just want to say a few words. Yesterday, I was ready to leave KACL.  To run away like I have from so many other challenges.  It was the support of one man, Frasier Crane, [_Frasier looks horrified at what he's done_] that helped me overcome this shyness many people may have observed in me, and to follow my dreams. [_crying_] Oh my God, I want to cry.

speaker: Gil
text: We all do.

speaker: Roz
text: [_angry_] Ten seconds! _Poppy gives a little shriek of excitement.  Everyone exits apart from Poppy, who puts on the headphones.  Roz to her booth.  Kenny, Gil and Frasier to the corridor._

speaker: Gil
text: How could you do this to us?

speaker: Frasier
text: I had no idea she intended to stay.

speaker: Kenny
text: That's not what her mother told me!

speaker: Gil
text: And I thought I'd seen some cruel pranks in the army.

speaker: Frasier
text: I assure you, she is way out of her depth here.  Any moment she'll realize she's in over her head, she'll be begging me to go in there and take over for her.

speaker: Poppy
text: [_slow, excruciating voice obviously reading from a script_] "A Streetcar Named Desire" is a very powerful Broadway play. It was made into a movie starring Marlon Brando.  This gave the play a very personal relevance to me, as I once sat next to Mr. Brando on the Concord and we had a very lovely chat until a sudden cramp forced him to change seats." _As Poppy's show continues, Frasier slowly collapses into a heap against the booth door in the corridor, almost crying at what he has done._

speaker: Poppy
text: "Streetcar" tells the tragic tale of [_Southern accent_] Blanche DuBois, who's a very gentile, very proper Southern lady. [_as if it is a horror movie_] Or is she?! _FADE TO:  Scene Three - Caf e Nervosa. Frasier enters the cafe to find Kenny, Gil and Roz chatting at a table. They all turn away from him and stop talking.  Roz puts her purse on the free seat, forcing Frasier to sit with his brother.  Rather than looking smug, however, Niles looks strangely sympathetic. _

speaker: Frasier
text: Go ahead, Niles, I know you were listening.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I wish you'd lent _her_ your Tennessee Williams's biography.  She wouldn't have kept forgetting his name and calling him "Indiana Jones."

speaker: Niles
text: If it's any consolation, I got fired from "The Monocle."

speaker: Frasier
text: [_stops the smile creeping to his face_] Niles, I'm sorry.

speaker: Niles
text: I panned a wretched musical, not realizing the lead was the person who does Olga's hair.

speaker: Frasier
text: She fired you just to placate her hairdresser?

speaker: Niles
text: Electrolysist.  And if you'd ever seen her in a sundress, you'd forgive her as I have.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I am sorry, Niles.  Gosh, it's a shame, really.  You know, I know how much you loved that job, and to lose it in such an unceremonious fashion.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you know... I was thinking of quitting that job anyway.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh?

speaker: Niles
text: I thought I was spreading myself too thin.  Getting distracted from my real work.

speaker: Frasier
text: I had the exact same thought.  Even as I was preparing my show, I thought, "Am I being fair to my regular listeners?"

speaker: Niles
text: They do depend on you.

speaker: Frasier
text: As do your patients.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: God, is it any wonder we find ourselves ex-critics?

speaker: Niles
text: We were meant to lose those jobs.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's as if the Gods of psychiatry, jealous of our dallyings, have quietly stepped in and put things right.

speaker: Niles
text: Well put!

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  You know, Niles, if you're feeling a bit hungry, we could catch an early dinner and then...

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, oh, and then catch the new Stoppard play.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, it's just a shame my listeners never got to hear my review of "Streetcar."

speaker: Niles
text: Insightful?

speaker: Frasier
text: Groundbreaking!

speaker: Niles
text: As was mine.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes well, it takes a psychiatrist to interpret that play.

speaker: Niles
text: Indeed.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, you go first.

speaker: Niles
text: All right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Go.

speaker: Niles
text: "A descent into madness, and it was well worth the trip in this incandescent revival of 'A Streetcar Named Desire'...."

speaker: Frasier
text: Just a moment Niles, "incandescent," isn't that the word they quoted you on in "The Times?"

speaker: Niles
text: Well, yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: You use that all the time. _Frasier and Niles continue bickering as they exit.  End of Act Two._
